Meanwhile, Henry uses his tech magic and Will uses his talk magic to realise that Abnormals from Hollow Earth took hostages at the camp in order to create a diversion away from a much larger invasion.

Hehehe. Crazy-pants is now my favourite word/phrase/thing. Thank you Henry.

Druitt is going to sacrifice his sanity/humanity so Helen can get to Worth. I do hope this means Druitt will be the sadistic bad guy again and not just, y’know, die.

Turns out the sacrifice is still too late. A time portal opens up and Worth steps through.

Helen walks through, not even looking back at Druitt.

Henry’s woobie face as he realises the scale of the invasion.

Who knew the 19th century had such CGI? Soo, Helen is stuck there. That’s quite a nice, fanfic-fodder of a cliff-hanger!

A very intense episode but it was the finale, so that was only to be expected. Cliff-hangers don’t really bother me, but I’m looking forward to see it being resolved.

It’s a pity that Tesla wasn’t in this episode, but I’m sure the fanfic writers will make up for that.

I'm a huge fan of time travel and this has made me personally happy. I planned a SL for a small fandom RP of mine which involved Jack the Ripper and time travel, but the RP disbanded before it got to be played out. Looking forward to see how Helen handles this.

As for me, it’s probably a good thing I’m really busy lately or I would be SUPER tempted to write some dark!Druitt fic. And some woobie!Henry fic. Probably both.

Anyway, I have ranted enough. What are your thoughts about the ep and my little picspam/review thing?

Fandom: Cumberholmes RPish
Title: Office Romance
Pairing: Gregson/Lestrade
Rating: PG-13. It’s pretty tame, a few swearwords and kisses. That’s it.
Wordcount: 2500ish
Summary: Pretty much just events from the RP: Gregson and Lestrade working on the case, bonding over coffee and paperwork, then the running after the suspect, and the mud. It was going to end there, until Lestrade reminded me that he was trying to get rid of the mud. Honestly, I don’t have a dirty imagination... even after that I still somehow managed to write fluff! Proof that I am a true romantic at heart.
Disclaimer: I am not to blame for this! I can’t lay claim on the original Arthur Conan Doyle series, or the BBC modernisation, or indeed the Cumberholmes RP. Oh. This is FICTION!!!
Author’s Note: I started this whilst waiting for Lestrade’s press statement. I’ve probably got a few details wrong but I just can’t believe I’m writing Lestrade/Gregson! I've changed it all to present tense, since that's the only one I can write consistently. I suck at tenses. And other things. Constructive Criticism will be much appreciated.

Title: Beautiful
Pairing: John/Sherlock
Rating: NC-17 because although nothing actually happens in the fic, what Sherlock talks about is very dark.
Summary: Being beautiful is a bad thing.
Wordcount: 2200ish
Warnings: Sherlock has attracted scumbags all his life and he’s suffered so much. I’m talking sexual abuse of a child, underage prostitution. Please don’t read this if you don’t feel you can handle it. Breaking Sherlock is enough for me; I really don’t want to hurt any real people. If there are any other warnings you think I should put here, please tell me.
Author’s Note: I originally wrote this fic for a different fandom but I hope it doesn’t show (apart from Sherlock being SO emotional, which I hope is understandable). Any slip ups, please feel free to let me know. I altered it for the   meme
Disclaimer: I don’t own Sherlock. No money made from this.

 

 

 

Beautiful

 


“Hey Freak,” Sally taunts. “You gonna look at the body or what? Quit posing then and start working.” Sally tells him. “Just ‘cause you look like a model, don’t mean anyone’s gonna take your picture-“ Sherlock cuts Sally off, rattling off a list of things pertinent to the case. Sally can’t tell if Sherlock is being his normal, arrogant self or if she’s upset him, he’s acting a little scared but either way, she says nothing and just notes down what he says.

********************

“Where were you last Saturday night at 9:15?” Lestrade asks the suspect, a little unnerved by Sherlock’s presence but permitting it because it probably unnerves the suspect just the same.

“I was digging up your mama’s grave.” Apparently it doesn’t.


“Really?” Sherlock smiles, amused. “All by yourself? Must have been terribly hard.”


“No. Your sister helped me!”


“Mr. Birkin, what were you doing at the time of the murder?” Lestrade sighs.


“Fuckin’ your pretty boy’s twin here.” He blows Sherlock a kiss and Lestrade watches as the colour drains from Sherlock’s face. Lestrade had been expecting a sharp response, Sherlock flaunting his intelligence to convict the idiot but no... Sherlock looks pale, as if he’s going to throw up, his hands shaking as he leaves the room. Lestrade wants to follow, he so desperately wants to see if he’s okay but there’s still a suspect in the room, he still has a job to do.


Lestrade texts John.

********************

It was the end of a long, tough case but they had caught the murderer. Sherlock lost track of time hours ago but John has been keeping an eagle eye on him, had someone track his movements when he couldn’t. He knows Sherlock has worked 59 hours straight, mind working overtime and not even able to rest once Lestrade had caught the murderer. Just one murderer, but a very clever murderer.


John’s not even sure if Sherlock has eaten. Sherlock can be so stubborn, so pervasive, ignoring John’s pleas to basically look after himself and instead he just concentrates on work and won’t rest until it is over. John realises he’s being hypocritical but Sherlock’s always takes it to the extremes and pushes limits. And it never ends, not really. It’s just one case after another and John makes it his job to take out the battery of Sherlock’s mobile before the next call comes. It’s become routine:


Sherlock works nonstop until he’s exhausted and his body is running on fumes. John has to schedule Sherlock some time off or he’d burn out. John has to take that time off too to ensure Sherlock refuels and rests. He sleeps more in John’s bed than he does in his own. John is beginning to wish he could catch Sherlock when he’s fit enough to do a little more than just sleep.


But John follows the routine every time and now Sherlock is passed out on the couch, dressed in his boxers and vest. He fell asleep before John could get some food inside of him, and that was twelve hours ago. John has to be at work in two hours and he’s wants to make sure Sherlock’s looked after before he goes. Without even thinking about it, John ruffles Sherlock’s hair.


“Wake up sleeping beauty.” John mutters, and is shocked by the way Sherlock bolts upright, as if waking from a nightmare. Sherlock is gone before John even knows what happened.


Ten minutes later and John finally tracks Sherlock down to a back-alley. Sherlock’s crying, and shaking, pale as a ghost and John freezes. The last ten minutes have been almost frantic for John, searching for Sherlock and now that he’s found him, time stops for just a second, before John takes a deep breath and approaches slowly.


“Sleeping beauty?” John asks and Sherlock flinches.


“It’s a fucked up fairytale.” Sherlock shrugs, but John isn’t buying it.


“Do you want to talk?” John offers.


“You don’t want to listen.” Sherlock chokes.


“I have to listen, Sherlock.”


“I know, I know, you’re my Doctor. You need to know of anything that could compromise my behaviour and force Lestrade to solve crimes on his own for a change.”


“Perhaps,” John admits. “But I *want* to listen because you’re my friend and I care about you.”


“I don’t know what to tell you John. I can’t tell you the reason for my reaction.”


“You don’t know why?” John probes.


“I try not to remember.” Sherlock sniffs, brushing away another stray tear.


“How’s that working for you?” John asks, making Sherlock laugh, before breaking down into tears. John shoves his hands in his pockets, trying to quell the urge to reach out and touch Sherlock, it would probably freak Sherlock out even more and John is not prepared for the surge of emotions touching Sherlock could bring out in himself. “It’s natural that we want to repress traumatic memories, but they have a way of breaking out. Certain words, sensations... can act as a trigger, and all those things that you’re repressing, they hit you at all once. Your behaviour-“


“My behaviour is inexcusable and uncontrollable John! You should know, you’ve told me enough times.”


“I was wrong!” John admits. “I was short-sighted. Too worried about how your behaviour made me look to try and figure out *why* you behave the way you do.”


“You’re making excuses for me John.” Sherlock warns him.


“I don’t think so.” John replies. “The way you act, it’s like you’re pushing people away. You don’t talk Sherlock!”


“I’m not crazy.” Sherlock insists. “I don’t want to talk to some... psychotherapist.”


“Then talk to me.” John pleads.


“You’re willing to play Freud so you have a flat-mate who’ll tow the line, will do as he’s told?”


“That would be nice.” John admits with a smile. “But I’m willing to play Freud to figure out why my friend freaked out because I implied he was beautiful.” Sherlock looks at John, eyes wide with fear and John can tell he’s fighting the urge to run again. John loses the battle with his own urges, and he allows his hand to fall on Sherlock’s shoulder, feeling Sherlock’s cold skin. “That’s what it is, isn’t it?”


“I don’t know what-“


“Yes you do Sherlock, you’re not that stupid.” Sherlock glares a little but John doesn’t back away. “You can tell me anything. You know that, don’t you?”


“I know that John. I’m just not sure I can...”


“I know this is hard. Take your time, I’m in no hurry.” John doesn’t know when it happened, but work can wait. Sherlock is his first priority.


“I can’t!” Sherlock crumbles, breaking into tears, sobbing so hard that it scares John. Sherlock sinks to the dirty floor. John places a steady hand on Sherlock’s shoulder. The skin is cold under his touch, so John puts his jacket round Sherlock. Trying not to let his emotions rule his head, he tries to remain passive, but in the end he gives in and holds Sherlock, clutching him close whilst waiting for the sobs to subside.


Sherlock is dehydrated, the tears stop after about ten minutes, but he is still shaking so John is still holding him, stroking his back. John’s not even trying to hide his own tears. It’s been a while since he’s cried for anybody but himself.


“You are so beautiful.” John tells him. “And passionate. And strong. And courageous. And amazing. I think you’re amazing.” And that makes Sherlock look at him, red eyed with drying tears down his cheeks. John resists the urge to brush the moisture away, but something must show in his eyes because Sherlock looks away.


“I was ten. When it first happened.” Sherlock takes a shaky breath. “My father and I got into a gypsy cab. The driver beat up my dad and I tried to stop him but he kept throwing me to the ground. Every time he threw me down I’d get up and go back to my father, he was bleeding so bad, saying curses I’d never even heard before. Then he stopped screaming and I ran to him, I tried to run but the driver... he just picked me up and threw me in the back of his cab and drove off.


“I don’t know what happened after that, I swear John. I remember hearing his voice, telling me I was a good boy, that I was special, that I was beautiful. I remember pretending it was a nightmare, and praying that I’d wake up any second. Mummy said it was four days before the police found me. I remember how scratchy the blanket was, that one the cop wrapped me in. It changed the way mummy looked at me after that. Like I disappointed her. Like I disgusted her. I didn’t know why she hated me. I understood why Mycroft hated me, for scaring mom, for not being able to protect pa-“


“You were just a kid.” John reminds him.


“I know.” Because Sherlock does. “But that was just the start of it.” And John swallows, as he realises how deep this goes. “It was like they could smell it on me after that. Cops. Criminals. And it was better to let them take what they want, give them want they wanted because otherwise they’d beat me and take it anyway. When I was fourteen I realised I could sell what everybody took. Maybe earn enough money to get out of here, make a fresh start. It was easy just to close my eyes and pretend I was somewhere else. If I didn’t eat it couldn’t make me sick. If I kept moving no one would notice that I couldn’t sit still. But even when I closed my eyes I could still hear the words. They’d fuck me ‘til I bled and then call me ‘baby’! I had to take drugs, just so I could bare it.”


“You got out. You got clean. You survived.” John tells him earnestly.


“Because of Lestrade.” Sherlock admits. “He almost arrested me when I was high. I practically threw myself at him but he didn’t take advantage. It was confusing. I became obsessed with him. A mystery to solve. He noticed that. The idiot he is, he noticed that. He helped me get clean, giving me mysteries as my reward. My first lucid thought was that I finally knew what I wanted to do with my life.”


“Become a consulting detective?” John questions, trying to make sure he’s following Sherlock’s story.


“It was something to do.” Sherlock smiles. “I was perfectly fine working on my own, Lestrade coming to me occasionally. I was clean and just about managing to keep the boredom away. For the most part. I was happy. A little bit of a recluse but it was better that way. People always want things from me. Lestrade too but at least he only wants me for my mind. Everything was going fine and then you were foolish enough to split the rent with me and I’ve been your problem ever since.”


“Sherlock, you’re worth the trouble.” John states. “Professionally and personally.” Then John’s phone rings. “It’s Sarah.”


“You better go.” Sherlock says. John cancels the call. He’ll call her back in a minute. “I might pop down Scotland Yard. See if Lestrade has anything interesting he’s too stubborn to tell me about.” He tells John. “I mean, I know I’m a mess but I clean up pretty good.” Sherlock snorts. “That’s the problem I guess.”


“I need you... to go back home and get some breakfast inside of you.”


“Nonsense, I don’t need to eat for at least a couple of days.” John glares at Sherlock, Sherlock looks suitably reprimanded and slightly shocked. “I could always grab something on the way to the Yard.” Sherlock suggests and John sighs.


“You could, but you’d have to get dressed first.” John points out and Sherlock blushes. John hands Sherlock his set of keys. “Sherlock, please. Go back home, fix yourself a decent breakfast, take your time, read a paper, savour it. Take a shower. Relax. Surf the internet. And if you still get bored? Then you can go pester Lestrade for work.” John promises.


“So I’ll see him in a couple of hours then.” Sherlock replies, making John laugh.


“Probably.” John admits and the silence spreads between them. John knows he’s got to go, Sarah is bound to call him again and she’ll already be pissed he hung up on her the first time. It just feels like there are still things left unsaid. Sherlock has told all there is to tell though, it’s John who is still holding back. “Sherlock?”


“Yeah?” John takes a deep breath and hopes for the best. His heart swells as Sherlock stands up and takes a step closer to him. Pale eyes looking at him with such pain, such hope, such beauty.


“Even if you were born ugly... I’d still find you beautiful.” John kisses Sherlock, chastely on the lips. “That’s not a bad thing, is it?” Sherlock smiles as he realises, no it’s not. Not at all.

 

FIN

Harry versus the Hospital


It was a dreadful crash
Lucky to survive
I knew there was a reason
Why I refuse to learn to drive

 

In a coma
Whilst her loved ones did fret
Although her brother was busy being rescued
So he didn’t know about the crash just yet

 

A list of injuries
As long as the arm of the law
And yet it was the mirror
Which made her scream at what she saw

 

Harry is a trouper
At handling the pain
Okay, so that might be the drugs
But I admire her, all the same

 

I want to snuggle close
So grateful she’ll be okay
I never wanted to leave her
But alas I couldn’t stay

 

At least she has her brother
With audio-books and comfy jumpers to keep her sane
Happy to be alive
But hospital is a bane

 

So imagine the relief
When the staff felt fit to declare
They would be taking Harry for a walk
Even if it was in a wheelchair

 

Driven around
Not allowed to steer herself
Of course not
That would be detrimental to her health!

 

Instead she ended up in a lift
Which broke down between floors seven and eight
The orderly with her
In a rather panicked state

 

Poor Harry, stuck in a wheelchair
Which was then in a lift that was stuck
At least she was safe
But still it is terrible luck

 

Then of course
The lights had to go out
But bless Harry Watson
Tweeting throughout

 

Then the doors opened
To reveal a wall
Poor Harry
That wasn’t helpful at all

 

Finally the lift started to move
But the gap was too big for Harry to “jump”
Stuck in her chair
But the porter practically flew out. Such a chump!

 

Then the lift was lowered
So Harry could wheel out, just to head...
Back to her room
Back to her bed

 

Visiting hours over
Nothing to look forward to
Except for the food
And hospital food is kind of... ew.

 

It sounds like you had a sucky day Harry
I’m sorry I couldn’t be there
So I documented your day
Just so you know how much I care

 

Hospital sounds dull
And you’ll probably be there for a while
But hopefully you’ll think of me
And I’ll try to make you smile

An Elegy for the Ill

 

The weakness of the human body
Always disappointing
But for once I’m well
So don’t mind me laughing, pointing

 

At least Holmes has recovered
Well enough to bicker
Though he’s no longer feverish
Others have gotten sicker

 

I do pity poor Anderson
I have no envy for his head
Drinking when already ill
But apparently he feels less dead

 

Although I do feel guilty
For writing about Lestrade
I hope that he feels better
Because he works so hard


I fear I may of mocked
Some of the sickly cries
I fear I may have cursed poor Kim
If you fall ill I do apologise
 

I also spare a thought
For those who have been recently shot
Although in Irene's case
She may have deserved what she got
 

And poor not!dead Molly Hooper
Suffering silently with the flu
Even if she’s still friends with Jim
She deserves some pity too

 

And speaking of Mr Moriarty
He’s feeling rather ill
To hear of his discomfort
Gives me such a thrill

 

As does Seb Moran
Jim’s faithful sidekick
It’s rather satisfying
To know he’s fallen sick

 

For Moran and Moriarty
I am over the moon
But to everyone else
I hope you get well soon

A for Anderson

 

You are not my usual muse
But still, I want to try
Yet I find this difficult
And I don’t know why

 

I guess that I don’t know you
But you seem okay
The beard is slightly scary
If I’m allowed to say

 

I know it can’t be easy
Working where you work
Still I don’t believe
That Holmes is such a jerk

 
At least it’s good to know
You appreciate a decent movie

The Man Inside His Office


The man inside his office
Is the man who is the boss
But he’s hiding in his office
And outside is at a loss

 

The man inside his office
Won’t come out to play
The man inside his office
Wishes I would go away

 

The man inside his office
Doesn’t like when I am kind
The man inside his office
Has other things upon his mind

 

The man inside his office
Has issues with his hair
Has issues with his looks
And pretends he doesn’t care

 

For the man inside his office

Because the man inside his office
Is a shy and timid boy

Ganymede Lestrade: Zeus’ Toy boy


Lestrade was going about his normal day
Keeping the peace, putting villains away
Working so hard to keep crime at bay
Whilst feeling tired, feeling grey

 

When called a fox, he didn’t believe
And grateful he was for any reprieve
From talk of how attractive others found him to be
He didn’t care. He just didn’t see.

 

Then, that day, Zeus came down from the sky
“Ganymede Lestrade” Zeus bellowed “Say goodbye.
To this Earth. Your Colleagues. To the Dead.
You now work for me instead.”

 

Lestrade gulps, “Perhaps this is the price I have to pay
To make the gossip-hounds go away.
If that is so, do what you will with me
Just make the fangirls leave me be.”

 

“Ganymede” Zeus smiled. “I only want what is fair.
To hold you close and play with your hair.
To gaze upon your beauty so rare.
You are mine and I don’t share.”

Fandom: Doctor Who
Title: Torture (07/08)
Characters: Rory and a new incarnation of The Master
Rating: NC-17 over all
Warning: This series includes death, mutilation and torture.
Word Count: 1550
Summary: Rory uses his last ounce of sanity to fight the Master.
Disclaimer: I really don’t own Doctor Who, this isn’t for profit.
Author’s Notes: written for  .

part one
part two
part three
part four
part five
part six

 

Torture

 

Rory punches the Master, hastily untying the rope that is binding his ankles so he can stand up on his feet. So weak he almost falls down again but he’s able to dodge when the Master tries to hit him. He makes a grab for the Master’s gun, the same one the Master shot his wife with. Rory holds the heavy weight in his hand, victorious, but then his hand starts to shake.

 

“You don’t have the strength to shoot me.” The Master sneers. “You’re a Nurse. You love people. You’re too weak to pull the trigger.”

 

“I am weak.” Rory admits. His mind flooded with all the times he never acted on what he wanted, all the times he lacked the courage. It’s tearing his mind apart and hurts so much but Rory tries to focus. He’s not the enemy here. The Master is the enemy. “But I have to kill you.”

 

“You don’t sound too sure about that.” The Master says, knowing Rory can’t be sure about anything, not with the amount of alternate realities flashing through his brain. There are probably even a few realities where the Master is the good guy. “You’re not a killer.”

 

“That’s where you’re wrong.” Rory states, tears falling down his cheeks as he remembers. He remembers acts that he didn’t commit, not in this timeline, not in this reality but he still knows them, he still recalls them and relives the experience. “I killed Amy. I killed the woman I love and I deserve to burn in hell for it. So do you.” Rory thinks of Chastity, so many different versions of her but not many were treated as well as they deserved. The Master is incapable of peaceful love.

 

“Then why don’t you shoot yourself?” The Master suggests. Rory falters.

 

“The thoughts would stop, but I can still see. I’m a bad man, evil, but I know you’re worse.” Rory argues. “The things you’ve done, the things you’re going to do... you used to have remorse but Time took it away.” Rory’s hand is shaking, he’s not strong enough to keep the gun steady because it weighs so much! It’s weighing him down. “There’s still good in you but you tell it shut up, you ignore, you torture the good in you. You’re in so much pain.”

 

“THEN PUT ME OUT OF MY MISERY!!!” The Master screams, surprised when Rory squeezes the trigger. The bullet tears through the Master’s flesh, through his back before becoming stuck in the wall. Rory stares in horror as he watches the Master looking down at his wound in surprise. Rory is in just as much shock, struggling to comprehend his actions, mind overcome with the possible consequences. Rory only has a few seconds to dwell on the time-line before the Master launches himself at Rory, scratching his face and Rory is forced to fire again and again until all the bullets have been expended and the Master’s body is full of holes.

 

Rory watches, his mind feeling as though it is pulsating and expanding, a flash of colours unfolding before his eyes. He can no longer trust them. He can’t trust him memories either. He can’t trust his own body, telling him false information. He tries to cling onto the fact that he just shot the evil man, he was forced to kill him and that he had no choice. The Master is dead, Rory can take comfort in that fact.

 

Nothing is fact, and Rory can scarce believe his eyes as he watches the Master’s face and body, change in front of him. His clothes are still bloody, his shirt still has the bullet-holes but Rory can see pale, living flesh through it. Rory cries as he realises what has happened.

 

“You can’t! You should be dead! Even for a Time Lord, you should be dead!” Rory declares desperately.

 

“I never played by their rules, even before they were extinct.” A charming English accent tells him. A man with blonde hair and a ginger goatee, he looks like a cliché villain, especially with the evil English enunciation. The man looks at him, the Master looks at Rory, and smiles. “It’s a shame I can’t take you with me. Perhaps we’ll meet again. Don’t know when, don’t know where-“ The Master starts crooning, a song Rory is sure he knows but he can’t quite recall, whether it’s a Gallifreyan lullaby or an Earth love song, or from another planet all together.

 

“You can’t leave!” Rory cries. He can’t. Rory shot him. He killed him. He killed the Master. He can just about understand the regeneration, he knows the tricks the Master has pulled before, the amount of times he has cheated the true death. But he can’t leave. The Master was stuck on this planet, stranded.

 

“Oh, but I can leave, thanks to you.” The Master, with a new face, tells him. He sounds so grateful, so charming. Rory has to remind himself that the Master is a psychopath. Rory also has to remind himself that this isn’t his fault. He has done everything he can to not give the Master what he wanted. “You have the Time Vortex running through your mind, Rory. You were a cooking pot. I was able to extract enough juice from you to get me any place, any time I want to go. It wouldn’t have worked, but your wedding ring made the most excellent energy manipulator and storage unit. It’s tuned into your frequency, as it were. I hope you don’t mind, but I’m going to have to keep it for now.”

 

“No!” Rory screams, his mind overloading. He wants to move, he wants to yell and beg and plead and crawl, he wants to launch himself at the Master but he’s in so much pain. He feels so sick.

 

“It’ll give you a good reason to come after me.” The Master smiles, his blue eyes sparkling.

 

“I will come after you. I’ll find you and I’ll kill you. I promise you that.” Rory declares, his face red with anger and frustration at the inability to act, rendered immobile by the pain and confusion. Rory can’t even turn his head away as the Master leans down to whisper in his ear.

 

“I look forward to it.” Then the Master presses some buttons on a device, and he’s gone. He could be anywhere through Time and Space and Rory tries to track down when and where but the Master is moving too fast, nothing constant, it’s making him dizzy, so hard to comprehend. He’s only human after all. He can’t cope with the Time Vortex in his mind. The Master is gone and Rory is beginning to forget what that means, what the Master has done to him, how he’s going to get out. Rory’s beginning to forget about Amy.

 

He tries to cling to her memory but he can’t feel her presence any more, he can’t feel the TARDIS’ energy, it’s been perverted by the energy inside his head, altering his thoughts, his senses. He knows he has to protect Amy but he can’t do that when he doesn’t know where she is. The Doctor, the Doctor would know. Rory needs to find the Doctor.

 

There’s no way out of the basement. A solid metal door with no handle. Rory is trapped. There are tools all around him, the Master’s gadgets, this was his workshop. If Rory could just focus he might be able to figure out, recreate the way the Master escaped, only make sure he travels though space and not time. There are too many variables.

 

Rory looks around, the room seemingly spinning. He can see a window, half a window, leading out to the street above but it’s too small for him to crawl through and it’s too high up for him to even reach. He can see out of it though. He can see the Doctor’s boots and he tries to scream, call out for him but something is wrong. The Doctor can’t hear Rory, even if he can it probably isn’t registering. The Doctor is moving so slowly. Rory is sick as he realises.

 

Wiping the bile from his mouth, he sobs. The realisation he’s trapped inside a time dilation field, it’s devastating. He probably hasn’t even been missed, if Amy and the Doctor would miss him to begin with. But Amy, Amy is gone, Rory feels that. He feels it physically.

 

He fears he may have killed her. Killed the one he loves. He can see it, remember it, he can still feel her blood on his hands. He can feel the skin of her throat as he choked her windpipe. He can see her die in so many different ways, not all by his hand, not many by his hand but horrifying all the same. To see Amy die of natural causes is heart-wrenching enough but to watch her murdered, dying tragically young, dying in the womb- Rory cannot bear to see more.

 

Rory scratches at his eyes until his surroundings go black and there is blood and vitreous fluid on his hands. He curls up in a corner, no longer able to look for the thing that would free him, though he can’t quite recall what that is. His mind is becoming overridden with the Time Vortex. Rory blacks out from blood loss, dehydration and exhaustion: Lost to the world.

Fandom: Sherlock
Title: Bleeding Heart
Pairing: Lestrade/Sherlock
Rating: PG-13 for some gore and mild sexual references
Word count: 3300
Summary: Moriarty goes after Lestrade and a relationship is revealed.
Disclaimer: I don’t own Sherlock Holmes in any of his incarnations. This is because the muses won’t let me sleep, not for profit.
Author’s Note: Written for   of course. So many prompts, so little time.

 

 

Bleeding Heart

 

There isn’t enough time for Sherlock to think properly, too many thoughts: inconsequential thoughts; unformed thoughts; woolly thoughts. It’s disorientating. When he came to the pool he thought he was calling the shots. Moriarty was keen to prove him wrong.

 

Sherlock doesn’t think he’s put on a bad show, matching Moriarty wit for wit but he’s running on adrenaline, acting off instinct. He can barely recall any of it.

 

He recalls the moment he first saw John. The brief, horrifying suspicion that somehow John was behind it all and that Sherlock would have to defeat John, bring him down.

 

Then Moriarty appeared and it was distracting, almost entertaining, if it weren’t for the nagging concern for John’s safety.

 

He remembers some of Moriarty’s threats, most of them were boring but there was one that sticks out in Sherlock’s memory. Moriarty threatened to “burn the heart out of him” and Sherlock finds that intriguing.

 

He remembers the relief when Moriarty left, the urgency with which he stripped John of his explosives-riddled jacked, the horrid stench of fear when Moriarty returns. But Sherlock has the gun and John has already made clear his willingness to die.

 

Sherlock is quite prepared to do it. Not just to end the tedium of his own life but to stop Moriarty from hurting others. Sherlock never realised he cared about that and perhaps he doesn’t, not really, but John and Lestrade seem to care. Moriarty would run rings around Lestrade, and Lestrade would run himself in the ground, trying to stop it, to stop the impossible. Lestrade would work himself to death.

 

No, Sherlock is the only one smart enough to stop Moriarty. And Sherlock wants to stop him. So he aims his gun at the explosives-riddled jacket, and prepares himself to pull the trigger.

 

“If you kill me now,” Moriarty smiles daggers. “This still continues. Pigs don’t taste very well when they’re full of copper and lead.” Sherlock freezes, his face draining of all blood until he looks like he’s going to faint. “If you don’t leave me alone, I’m going to make sure you’re left alone. All alone. Of course, I might do that, just for the fun of it.”

 

“You wouldn’t.” Sherlock spits, his hands shaking. “You wouldn’t dare!”

 

“Is that a challenge?” Moriarty grins, before slipping away into the darkness. John is still on the floor, but once he’s certain Moriarty is gone he’s angry enough at Sherlock to stand.

 

“What the hell was that?” John demands.

 

“I’ll catch him later.” Sherlock dismisses. “I’ve got to...” Sherlock starts by texting a number but he soon realises that isn’t sufficient. He needs his mind putting at rest now. “Pick up. Pick up!” Sherlock yells at the phone.

 

“Sherlock?” John shouts. “Sherlock?!” John doesn’t know what to ask. ‘Are you okay?’ is a stupid question in this situation, although Sherlock would insist he’s fine, even though it’s quite evident he’s rattled, to say the least. “What’s going on?” Sherlock ignores him, running off. John runs after him.

 

*****

 

“Sherlock.” John pants. “Where are we going?”

 

“Moriarty isn’t that stupid.” Sherlock mutters. “But why isn’t he answering?”

 

“Sherlock, what’s going on?”

 

“I guess he could be working a case, perhaps in a conference but it’s late, maybe he’s even getting some sleep. Ha, he needs it but I don’t know and Moriarty, he said, he threatened-“

 

“Wait, are we talking about Lestrade?” John asks, piecing together most of the pieces.

 

“Yes, Lestrade! We’re almost at his place. Hurry up!” Sherlock orders.

 

“Why are you so worried about Lestrade?” John questions but Sherlock has already run off into the distance.

 

*****

 

John catches up outside the door Sherlock is frantically throwing himself against. John has never seen Sherlock like this before, it’s rather unsettling. John tries to figure out why, using Holmes’ methods. He surveys the area. The building has been divided up for three separate tenants judging by the numbers on the door. John is able to deduce that Lestrade lives on the middle floor, by the bullet holes in the window. John helps Sherlock break the front door down.

 

John is surprised by the fact Sherlock uses a key to get into Lestrade’s room.

 

Perhaps it’s John’s time in Afghanistan but he feels oddly calm. Strangely detached as he observes Sherlock’s erratic behaviour; the desperation with which he searches the rooms; the terror in his voice as he calls out Lestrade’s name.

 

“Sherlock.” John finds Lestrade first. Lestrade is slumped over a desk, blood splatter on his laptop, a puddle of blood on the floor beneath him, dripping from the hole in his shoulder and his back. John barely has time to react before Sherlock is scooping the lifeless body into his arms, rolling the man’s head back to kiss his lips, placing him on the floor to start CPR. “Stop it, Sherlock. You’re making it worse!” John snaps, surprised by what he’s seen.

 

“I can’t do nothing!” Sherlock snaps back, tears leaking out of his eyes. He really must be upset if he’s using a double negative.

 

“Then call for an ambulance. You can give them the address.” John instructs. “And give me your scarf. He hasn’t got much blood left; we need to make sure what little he has remains inside his body.” Sherlock doesn’t respond. He’s shaking. “Sherlock!” Sherlock starts. He jumps into action, shoving his scarf into John’s hands and dialling 999 with a trembling hand.

 

Sherlock stutters instructions into the phone, desperation causing him to trip over his own words. John tends to Lestrade’s bloodless body, worried about the bullet in Lestrade’s back, no exit wound so it’s still inside his body doing untold damage. John can’t think about that, he just needs to keep Lestrade alive until the ambulance arrives. John can hear Sherlock, frantically begging over the phone for them to hurry, telling them the address and Lestrade’s blood type. Then Sherlock hangs up and falls gracelessly to the floor, his hand skimming under the fabric of Lestrade’s bloody shirt, resting over where his heart is, terrified when he barely feels a thing.

 

Sherlock is no longer speaking and John is too busy keeping Lestrade alive to pay attention to Sherlock.

 

They wait for the ambulance in silence.

 

*****

 

John is torn. Lestrade is rushed off to surgery and Sherlock is treated for shock. Sherlock doesn’t protest, he doesn’t do anything. Sherlock is catatonic. John feels helpless.

 

The adrenaline wears off and John falls asleep, his mind trying to make sense of the day: images of Moriarty flash through his mind, red dots and explosions, Lestrade’s blood and Sherlock’s heart breaking. He doesn’t wake up for thirteen hours but he wakes with a slightly clearer mind. His first instinct is to check on Sherlock but he dismisses that. He needs to know that Lestrade survived.

 

Lestrade did survive but there are ventilation machines breathing for him and he is still in a coma. John is concerned about that. The tests and scans are all positive but John can still recall the blood on his hands even though he’s washed them countless times since. John can’t know the damage until Lestrade wakes up. He can guess, his mind going to the worst possible scenarios and it’s unbearable.

 

He goes outside to throw up.

 

He doesn’t feel any better after he’s visited Sherlock. Still catatonic. No change. John tries to tell himself that it isn’t so worrying, it’s not unusual for Sherlock to not acknowledge people, not talk, not eat or not speak. What is unusual is the tear that has leaked from Sherlock’s wide open and vacant eyes. Sherlock is crying. John convinces the nurse not to fill Sherlock with drugs since the catatonic state is clearly emotional, not medical but he’s told it’s only a short reprieve, the nurse will return to complete his duties.

 

John goes outside to breathe and think, not knowing who to turn to, not knowing what to do.

 

*****

 

John comes to the conclusion that he needs to fix Sherlock first, because then Sherlock will inform him what to do next and probably mock him at the same time. John needs to fix Sherlock quick before the nurse pumps him full of benzodiazepines. He almost calls Mycroft but John doubts that wouldn’t work. He wouldn’t react to Mycroft.

 

The answer is so obvious he can almost hear Sherlock calling him an idiot.

 

He would react to Lestrade.

 

Now John just has to tackle the problem of how to get Sherlock to Lestrade. It’s easy enough to order a nurse to help him put Sherlock into a wheelchair: what isn’t so easy is to sneak him into Lestrade’s ward. John is stopped by a little middle-aged woman who looks far scarier than any security guard.

 

“Look, I know it’s not hospital policy but Sherlock NEEDS to know Lestrade is still alive.” John argues.

 

“Doesn’t look like he cares to me.” The woman answers back.

 

“Appearances can be deceiving.” John replies. He has seen two sides of Sherlock and he doesn’t know which one to believe. John never had a clue about Sherlock and Lestrade. “Lestrade.” John wonders. “Who’s his next of kin? Can you look it up?” She reluctantly takes her eyes off John to look at the computer screen.

 

“Sherlock Holmes. Partner.” She reads out, looking at Sherlock for the first time, her eyes suddenly overwhelmed with pity. “I’m sorry.”

 

“I’m Sherlock’s flatmate.” John tells her. “Last night, somebody kidnapped me and strapped a bomb to me in an attempt to get Sherlock to stop foiling a guy’s criminal activities. Sherlock was prepared to shoot the bomb; killing me, the bad guy and himself. Then the evil, evil man threatened Lestrade and Sherlock ran to Lestrade’s house. When we found him I thought we were too late. If we are to have a chance of catching the scumbag who did this, I need Sherlock. Please. It’s been a long few days. I just want to give this a try. I don’t think it could do any harm.” The woman blinks, trying to digest what John has just told her. “I’m a Doctor.” John continues. “I just want to help. I want them both to get better. I wouldn’t do anything to jeopardise that.”

 

“OK!” She gives in. “And good luck.”

 

*****

 

As soon as Lestrade is visible, Sherlock walks out of wheelchair and takes the seat next to Lestrade’s bed. He takes hold of Lestrade’s hand, careful of the IV drip.

 

“How is he?” Sherlock asks, his voice a little shaky but never-the-less, back to his usual demanding self.

 

“Alive.” John answers back, a little childishly, annoyed at Sherlock for putting him through so much worry and stress until he reminds himself that it’s better than the alternative. “We can’t really say more than that until he’s woken up.” John sighs, pulling up another chair and sitting down, making sure he can keep an eye on both Sherlock and on Lestrade. “The tests look positive but with the amount of blood loss he sustained...” John trails off. “The wound to the shoulder was a through and through but the bullet in his lower back... when he wakes up he could be paralysed or brain damaged, it’s impossible to know – why didn’t you tell me, Sherlock?”

 

“Huh? Tell you what?” Sherlock replies.

 

“About you and Lestrade.” John clarifies.

 

“What about Lestrade and me?” Sherlock asks.

 

“That you’re... together.” John answers. Sherlock laughs. “He is my friend, you know.”

 

“Then why didn’t he tell you?” Sherlock points out. John doesn’t know. “Because it’s nothing to him. He doesn’t even think about it.”

 

“He has you as his next of kin.” John notes. “That must mean something.”  

 

“It just means he hasn’t got anybody else.” Sherlock says bitterly. John shakes his head but knows better that to disagree with Sherlock. He doesn’t have the energy.

 

“So what is going on between you two?” John asks, curious.

 

“Do you really want to know?” Sherlock double checks. John can tell by the tilt of Sherlock’s head that he wants to tell the story. He wants to brag about his relationship with Lestrade. It’s almost endearing.

 

“Probably not.” John needs to appear reluctant, for masculinities sake. “Wait, is that what you meant when you told me you were ‘married to your work’?” Sherlock breaks into a grin.

 

“I was thinking of him, yes.” Sherlock realises he’s grinning and tries to hide it. “I waste far too much energy thinking about him. So many tiny little details, clogging up my hard drive but I can’t delete them. Stupid details, like how he takes his coffee, his favourite deodorant, favourite brand of toothpaste, his birthday-“

 

“What is his birthday, by the way?” John interrupts, curious.

 

“Oh no you don’t!” Sherlock smiles slyly. “That’s the only day of the year I get him all to myself. No annoying cases. I take the battery out of his mobile, take his phone of the hook, no distractions.”

 

“That almost sounds romantic.” John comments. Sherlock snorts.

 

“He hates it when I make a fuss over him.” Sherlock notes. “’It’s just another day. Nothing special.’” Sherlock mimics Lestrade, his accent changed. “His accent gets thicker after we’ve...” Sherlock blushes, not embarrassment but sheer happiness. John blinks, bemused.

 

“How long have you...?” John trails off, knowing Sherlock will get it.

 

“Twenty minutes after meeting him I may have confessed my love for him.” Sherlock smiles. John laughs, shaking his head.

 

“That’s lust, Sherlock. Not love.” John informs him.

 

“Perhaps.” Sherlock concedes. “But I did perceive the possibility of being in love in the future. It was rather exhilarating at the time. A little devastating that he didn’t believe me.” Sherlock frowns. “Depressing to think that he still doesn’t believe me.” Sherlock squeezes Lestrade’s hand just a little tighter before shaking off such sad thoughts. “But I solved the case for him. And he was so grateful. He needs me and he accepts that.

 

“I use to go crazy, waiting for him to call. Always for work, because that’s all there is, for him and for me.” Sherlock insists but John is beginning to doubt that. “But he’d only call me for the cases he couldn’t solve. The mysterious ones. The interesting ones.”

 

“That’s good, isn’t it?” John asks, confused. He knows Sherlock doesn’t like being pestered for trivial things.

 

“Not for him.” Sherlock answers back, sounding strangely concerned. “When I first saw him he was... overwhelmed and things got worse from there. I broke into his place a few weeks after we met. Just because I was bored. I wanted to see if he had any interesting cases for me.” That sounds like a lie but John doesn’t call him out on it. “At first I thought he wasn’t in but he was there. Sitting in the dark. Brain still buzzing with paperwork, personnel and a rather nasty child pornography ring he was stupid enough to stumble across. Sick to the stomach and exhausted but unable to sleep. He was a mess!”

 

“What did you do?” John prompts, a little enthralled.

 

“I kissed him.” Sherlock recalls, bewildered. “I let him talk to me. He cried a little and tried to apologise but I just kissed him to shut him up, told him he never needed to apologise, not to me, not to anybody. I wanted to make him forget.” Sherlock seems baffled by the notion. “So I did. But it never lasts.” Sherlock sighs. “He goes back to work and he lets it drain him, clogging up his brain and his heart and body with such unhealthy baggage. Why can’t he just stay in bed with me?” Sherlock asks, pouting a little.

 

“The world doesn’t work that way.” John says, knowing why it doesn’t but at the same time, kind of wishing it would. “Besides, you would get bored, without a puzzle to solve. Lestrade’s an open book.”

 

“He isn’t.” Sherlock argues. “He needs me but he pushes me away. Not about work, he always listens to me about work, when it will benefit others, not when it will benefit himself. He doesn’t expect me to stay, after we...” Sherlock trails off. “And I can never find the words to ask.” Sherlock seems angry with himself. “After five years I really should be able to ask. Or he should have realised that I’m not going anywhere. He needs me.”

 

“He may need you more now than ever.” John says, soberly. “If he wakes up-“

 

“When.” Sherlock corrects him.

 

“When he wakes up,” John continues, “he’ll probably be in a wheelchair, and with that shoulder he won’t be able to push himself. If his brain is working well enough, the scans say it is but the blood loss... “ John has a strange flashback to Afghanistan. “There has to be some repercussions.”

 

“He’s going to be fine!” Sherlock says staccato, like a mantra which has been going through his head.

 

“Mrs. Hudson has been toying with the idea of installing a lift.” John casually mentions. “For when her hip is acting up.”

 

“No.” Sherlock cuts John off. “I already asked him once and he said no.” John’s mouth pauses, open. He realises this in time and manages to close it before Sherlock calls him a fish. John stumbles over what to say.

 

“But this is different.” John argues.

 

“If he thinks you’re inviting him to live with us, just so you can take care of him, he will say no.” Sherlock states. John thinks about that.

 

“Then he has to live with me if he doesn’t want to be investigating your murder. You really can be an infuriating flatmate.” John states. “And if he doesn’t want to live with us, he can always take the room with the damp. He’d be doing Mrs. Hudson a favour. And it’s not like we’ll actually let him sleep down there. We could dump all your experiments there, so he has to join us.”

 

“Mrs. Hudson won’t be able to get permission to put a lift in.” Sherlock dismisses, although his eyes look hopeful. John can tell he wants Lestrade to live with them.

 

“I’m sure your brother would help, if it helped us keep you under control.” John smiles. “Does he know? About you and Lestrade?”

 

“Probably.” Sherlock concedes. “I don’t try and hide it.” John can see the love in Sherlock’s eyes and wonders why he never saw it before. It isn’t hidden. You just need to know what to look for.

 

John yawns against his will.

 

“I might head home.” John stretches. “Talk to Mrs. Hudson. Or Mycroft.” John’s eyes widen. “Or Sarah, I don’t think she knows why I never turned up!” John texts her. “You should think about getting some rest yourself.”

 

“I’m not leaving him.” Sherlock repeats. “Nobody can take me away from him. Not for good.” The last part is said with equal parts determination and anger. John suspects it’s directed at Moriarty.

 

“You did the right thing, letting Moriarty get away.” John decides. “Live to fight another day, and all that.”

 

“Dying is too good for him.” Sherlock spits. “I am going to burn him. I will track him down. Take away all his pawns and all his little chess pieces until he has no protection, nothing and no one to hide behind. And then I am going to let the police lock him up. Solitary. No human contact. No one for him to manipulate. I will have Mycroft himself watch the security feed. I won’t talk to him, I won’t engage with him, I won’t even acknowledge his existence. His mind will rot with boredom for what he’s done.” Sherlock’s hand strokes Lestrade’s pale and clammy cheek. “I will destroy him!”

 

“He was right about one thing.” John says flippantly. “You do have a heart.” John leaves with that comment.

 

Sherlock shakes his head. It isn’t his. Lestrade needs to wake up so he can take what belongs to him.

 

FIN

It started out as an experiment with colours. A Lestrade slideshow set to a fabulous tune from Doctor Who Season 3, the unreleased soundtrack. Images taken from Sherlock, which belongs to the BBC. This was done to occupy my six year old sister. She helped me pick the colours and organise the pictures. I'm really proud of her.

I've put all the images I edited in a photobucket folder: Lestrade's Edwardian Lullaby (I know the folder has no apostraphe, it bugs me)

There's also a downloadable version over at sendspace: Lestrade's Edwardian Lullaby about 6.5 MB, 1 min 25, and 51 images

   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 6" />

<![endif]-->  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><b style="">Fandom: </b>Sherlock... mostly<br /><b style="">Title: </b>Steam Shower (2/4)<br /><b style="">Pairing: </b>Rory/Lestrade<br /><b style="">Rating: </b>NC-17 for sex<br /><b style="">Word Count: </b>1275<br /><b style="">Summary: </b>Lestrade is still ill, but a steam shower does him the world of good.<br /><b style="">Disclaimer: </b>I don’t own Doctor Who, or Sherlock. I am very sorry about passing my cold onto Lestrade, but I’m all for sharing and it’s about the only thing I own. Feedback much appreciated.<br /><b style="">AN: </b>er, this is porn. I’m confused. Part of my ‘Follow the Flu’ verse. A follow-up to <a href="http://beautybecks.livejournal.com/73336.html">Doctor’s Orders</a>, but since this is a PWP it pretty much can be read alone. I think.<br /><o:p></o:p></p>                  <lj-cut text="Steam Shower"><p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><b style=""><u>Steam Shower<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><b style=""><u><o:p><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></o:p></u></b></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;">Rory wakes up alone.</p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;">For a brief second, he’s worried Greg has ignored both his and Dr. Watson’s warnings and gone to work anyway. That proves incorrect as he hears his lover suffering from the most terrible coughing fit downstairs.</p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;">By the time Rory has made his way down, the coughing fit has subsided a little. Greg is red-faced, a little sweaty with exertion but what Rory finds most worrying is the fact Lestrade’s lips are slightly purple. A similar shade of purple to the one that is starting to form underneath Lestrade’s red and tired eyes.</p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;">“Sorry, I didn’t wake you, did I?” Lestrade apologises.</p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;">“Why did you sleep on the couch?” Rory enquires, automatically enfolding his arms around Greg, pulling him into an embrace that Lestrade is too tired to fight.</p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;">“I couldn’t sleep. Didn’t want to wake you.” The argument is circular. It looks like Lestrade had given up on sleep, the laptop open and on. Not that’s he’s been able to get much work done, not with how lousy he feels. Lestrade is squinting at the screen, his vision obviously somewhat blurred, and the second he tries typing, he has a coughing fit which ends up in phlegm being projected onto the screen. “God, that’s gross!” Lestrade rushes to wipe the phlegm up with the numerous tissues he’s used. “Sorry.”</p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify;">“I’ve seen worse.” Rory reminds him. “You’ve got acute bronchitis. Rory always thought of himself as being pathetically shy. It’s rather endearing to find an older man so insecure. <![endif]-->  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><b style="">Fandom: </b>Sherlock... mostly<br /><b style="">Title: </b>Doctor’s Orders<br /><b style="">Pairing: </b>Rory/Lestrade with John.<br /><b style="">Rating: </b>PG-13 for snot and swearing<br /><b style="">Word Count: </b>790<br /><b style="">Summary: </b>Lestrade is ill, but he still wants to work, much to Nurse Rory’s chagrin. Rory has to call in reinforcements.<br /><b style="">Disclaimer: </b>I don’t own Doctor Who, or Sherlock. I am very sorry about passing my cold onto Lestrade, but I’m all for sharing and it’s about the only thing I own. Feedback much appreciated.</p>              <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p></o:p></p>  <lj-cut text="Doctor's Orders"><p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><b style=""><u>Doctor’s Orders<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><b style=""><u><o:p><span style="text-decoration: none;"> </span></o:p></u></b></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“I got your text.” John announces. “You said it was urgent. What’s wrong?”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“He is.” Rory says simply. John follows Rory’s gaze over to the couch, where a rather grey looking Lestrade is struggling to get into his coat. He is clutching a briefcase, and struggling to keep his eyes open.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Lestrade?” John asks. Lestrade blinks several times, before realising it is John. He sinks back onto the couch.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Please tell him he isn’t fit to go to work.” Rory pleads.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“What?” John asks, incredulously. “Do I have to? He can barely stand!”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“I can hear you, you know.” Lestrade croaks, his voice pitifully weak.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“He can barely speak.” John continues. “Lestrade, you can’t seriously be wanting to go to work.” John is subjected to an extremely pathetic look, those brown eyes conveying stubborn determination.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“I don’t <i style="">want</i> to go to work.” Lestrade admits. “But the paperwork isn’t going to write, fill or file itself.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Greg!” Rory tries again. “You’re not well. You really should rest.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“I can’t rest. Not whilst there’s work to be done.” Lestrade replies. “Shouldn’t you be going to work? It is flu season. I hardly ever see round this time of year. Shouldn’t you be going round the nursing homes, giving the elderly their flu vaccinations?”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“I’d rather be here.” Rory says.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Well, I don’t want you here.” Lestrade snaps. “I don’t want to be here. I need to be at the office.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“You’re a jerk, do you know that?” John cries. “You and your boyfriend, saving the city, making the rest of us look bad. Give it a break for once, will you? Please!”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“I can’t.” Lestrade sniffs. “I’m not like you. I’m not smart like Sherlock. I’m not brave like you. I’m not gentle, like Rory. I’m not special but I am dependable. I’m reliable. Without that, I’m nothing.” Rory can see John crumbling, tempted to help Greg go to work.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Woah, what kind of Doctor are you?” Rory asks. “I know I’m a sucker for his puppy dog eyes, that’s a given, but you’re supposed to have a little more resistance.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“You’re right.” John admits. “I don’t know what came over me. Lestrade, shut up. Rest your voice. Rest full stop. And stop looking at me like that, you can’t intimidate me.” John really shouldn’t be intimidated. Lestrade is glaring at him through half-closed eyes, red-rimmed with black shadows underneath. He looks very sick but still so determined. “Er, Rory?”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Greg, please!” Rory implores. “You can’t bully us into letting you work.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“You can’t stop me.” Lestrade replies. “You two should be working yourself. Helping the sick.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“We’re trying to help you.” Rory answers, but Lestrade just shrugs it off. He’s managed to get on his coat; he’s still clutching his briefcase. He starts walking to the door.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Don’t make me call Sherlock.” John hastily says.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Fuck Sherlock!” Lestrade declares in a fit of anger which provokes a nasty coughing fit, one that leaves him whimpering afterwards. “So fucking smug, acting like he’s the bloody boss of me. Told me I was contaminating *his* crime scene, ordered me to go home. Arrogant bastard!”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Greg, calm down.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“So that explains what Sherlock was on about!” John exclaims. “Sherlock told me I’d get a text from Rory. He also said you’re an idiot for taking such poor care of yourself, especially when you’ve got people willing to do it for you. He says you’re smart enough to accept help from him, but too foolish to help yourself. Not that he cares if you go to work ill. He made that explicit. He doesn’t care if you feel rotten. None of his business. Then he told me to go and check on you. And that’s when I got Rory’s text.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Following orders.” Lestrade sympathises. John looks at Rory, but Rory’s shaking his head. If Lestrade were to realise John was here of his own free will, through little coercion, Lestrade would be out of the door as fast as his dizziness and nausea permit.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Yes.” John lies. “Just like you need to follow Doctor’s orders. Although Nurse and boyfriend orders really should be enough.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Yeah, I’m a lousy boyfriend. Tell me something I don’t know.” Lestrade sighs, still eyeing the door.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“That your boyfriend wants to take you to bed and rub Vicks Vaporub into your chest.” John smirks, letting that sink in and watching the blush creep on Lestrade’s cheeks as it does. “Don’t worry. I won’t tell Sherlock he was right.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Thank you.” Lestrade smiles, before collapsing back onto the couch.</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Yeah, thanks.” Rory smiles, his arm around Lestrade as he helps Greg to bed, trusting John to let himself out. “You heard the man. Doctor’s orders.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">“Yes, Nurse Williams.”</p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"><o:p> </o:p></p>  <p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing">FIN</p></lj-cut><p style="text-align: justify;" class="MsoNoSpacing"> </p></meta></meta></meta></meta>

Fandom: Sherlock
Title: The Case of Blind Beauty
Pairing: Sherlock/Lestrade
Word Count: 5000 (in two parts thanks to LJ)
Rating: NC-17
Summary: Lestrade doesn’t believe he’s beautiful enough for Sherlock to stay in love with him. Can Sherlock convince him otherwise?
Disclaimer: I’m not ACD, or the Moff, or Gatiss, or Aunty Beeb. No profit is being made from this.
Author’s note: written for a   prompt.  I needed to write something porny in between all my angst fics. Instead, I wrote angst with the teeniest bit of porn.

part one

The Case of Blind Beauty

It’s 2:36am but Sherlock is still awake, talking to John because John is reluctant to leave him alone when his heart is so raw and exposed. Yes, Sherlock is well aware he’s being melodramatic but it is how he feels.

 

Sherlock’s heart metaphorically skips a beat as he receives a text. It’s from Lestrade.

 

Sorry, it’s so late. Early.

I’m outside.

Please can you let me in?

GL

 

Sherlock shows John the text, panicking slightly, even though it’s what Sherlock wants.

 

“Don’t worry.” John says, calmly, “You stay here and relax. I’ll let him in on my way out.”

 

“You’re going out?” Sherlock asks, surprised.

 

“Mrs. Hudson may have bought popcorn but it’s a show I’d rather miss,” John can see Sherlock’s confused. “Don’t worry, Lestrade wouldn’t know what I’m on about either. You two actually make the perfect couple, once you get passed his self-doubt and your self-centeredness. Which I’m sure you will. See ya.” John rushes down, grabbing his coat on the way because it’s raining.

 

Sherlock stays where he is, picking at the red material of his pyjamas. He needs this to go well. He can’t take it if George were to end it. Again. But if that were the case, surely John wouldn’t leave?

 

“George?” Sherlock asks, standing up, hoping George will hurry up, even though he knows his knees will give way the second he sees him.

 

“Sherlock, I’m sorry if I woke you.” Lestrade apologises.

 

“I wasn’t sleeping.” Sherlock assures him. “I couldn’t sleep. Please, come inside.” Lestrade is lingering on the staircase. “Please.”

 

“I’m dripping on your floor.” Lestrade says, apologising again. “I’m a mess.” Sherlock is literally moved by that, meeting George out on the stairwell.

 

“You’re beautiful.” Sherlock tells him, confused and terrified because that statement makes George pause before turning to leave so Sherlock has no choice but to put his arm out, holding George in place. “Why is that so hard for you to hear? Have I ever given you cause to doubt me?”

 

“You say you’re a sociopath.” Lestrade points out.

 

“That doesn’t mean I can’t appreciate beauty.” Sherlock argues.

 

“Then you shouldn’t appreciate me.” Lestrade shrugs free and starts to leave.

 

“Please don’t go!” Sherlock cries. He actually breaks down and cries, not caring about dignity.

 

“I don’t want to hurt you.” George says, confused because Sherlock does sound like he’s hurting. A lot.

 

“Then stay.” Sherlock begs. His hands on George, forcing George to look into his eyes. “Kiss me better.” Sherlock ventures, hopefully. George can’t resist.

 

The kiss starts out so shyly, so tender that its takes all of Sherlock’s efforts not to break down and cry again. It feels so good to have George’s lips against his own, it makes him feel so many things, drowning in sensation and causing all thoughts to leave his head but Sherlock loves that. His mind, silent for once as his body is screaming, desperate for more so he deepens the kiss, one hand threading through George’s silver hair, the other hand on George’s wet coat, pushing them closer. He feels at a loss when George pulls back, panting slightly, Sherlock left gasping.

 

“Feeling better?” George asks bashfully. Sherlock pulls George into a hug, not even caring that he’s getting his pyjamas soaked, it’s worth it. He needs to feel close to Lestrade.

 

“I feel so happy I could cry.” Sherlock replies, whispering into George’s ear.

 

“Please, no more crying.” Lestrade pleads, Sherlock finds himself stroking George’s stubbled cheek and kissing at his lips.

 

“Come inside.” Sherlock urges him. “Let me take your coat.” Sherlock takes Lestrade’s long coat, not that it has done much good, George never even fastened it. He sees how George’s jacket is missing, his open shirt is soaked down the front and the back of the neck. “Warm you up.” Sherlock moves the paperwork off the electric heater and switches it on. “It’s good to see you.” Sherlock says, once the conversation has lapsed for a significant period of time. George is being scarily silent. “Are you okay?” Such a poor word, ‘okay’. Such a sociological cliché but Sherlock has been reduced to it.

 

“I read your letter.” George says. “I don’t know what to make of it.”

 

“That I love you- I do wish you’d stop wincing whenever I say that.” Sherlock notes.

 

“You’re not that stupid.” George dismisses.

 

“Apparently, I am that human. A terrible realisation I know, but I’m really rather grateful for it.” Sherlock states before elaborating. “It may cause tremendous pain, being in love, but it’s never boring.”

 

“But I’M boring.” George argues. Sherlock smiles.

 

“Even if that were true, the feelings you instil in me are far from it.” Sherlock admits. “I could never tire of you.”

 

“I wish I were so sure.” George mutters. Sherlock crosses the living room to where George is still loitering in the doorway. He kisses George, firmly.

 

“Then let me be confident enough for the both of us.” Sherlock tells him, pulling him into another kiss, a heated one. A kiss with passion and confidence and lust; powerful lust that Sherlock is sick of hiding. His mouth is burning from the stubble of George’s chin but it feels so good, Sherlock doesn’t hold back the moan it induces. George’s head falls back, exposing his neck and Sherlock just has to dip down to caress it with his tongue and lips, nibbling just a little with his teeth, wanted to mark George’s flesh, mark him as his own, forever and always.

 

Sherlock resists that urge, for now, not wanting to scare George away. His hands are busy fumbling with the buttons of George’s wet shirt, careful not to tear any off, despite his desperation. He kisses his way down George’s hairy chest whilst his hands struggle with George’s belt and zipper.

 

George keeps trying to speak, false protestations and insecurities. Every time they try to voice themselves Sherlock straightens up and kisses George on the mouth, his tongue silencing George’s tongue before continuing down its journey down George’s body, latching onto a nipple or dipping into George’s bellybutton, taking the scenic route before it reaches its destination.

 

Sherlock is on his knees when he frees George’s cock from the confines of his blue boxer shorts. Sherlock has to swallow against the sudden rush on moisture in his mouth. He tries to regulate his breathing but the anticipation makes it difficult, panting, hot breaths against George’s cock. Most men would have their hands in Sherlock’s hair and be forcing him to suck their cock, but not George. George is waiting patiently, still not understanding that Sherlock wants this, he needs it.

 

There’s little finesse in the blowjob. Sherlock is so hungry for it, for the taste, for the texture, for the fact that this is George’s dick, Sherlock forgets things like rhythm and other variables: he does what feels best for him. This includes running his tongue down George’s shaft before using one hand to hold the dick in place as his tongue laps the head. Sherlock loses all composure as he needs to feel the dick in his mouth, hitting the back of his throat in a way that would make lesser men gag. He needs to feel George inside him, fucking him, preferably up the arse but that takes time and preparation, so even though his rectal muscles twitch with desire Sherlock gladly settles for this, letting George fuck his mouth even though George is remaining frustratingly passive, hardly moving his hips, no doubt unwilling to hurt him.

 

Sherlock growls in frustration, bobbing his head back and forth, both hands now on George’s hips, desperate for George to lose all self-control until, finally, finally George starts rocking his hips slightly, leaning into Sherlock’s mouth, forcing himself deeper as Sherlock keeps sucking, his jaw aching and his throat bruised but he keeps his lips wrapped around George’s cock because it feels so right.

 

George warns Sherlock that he’s about to come, so Sherlock pulls back, just slightly as he milks George dry. The bitter taste flooding his tastebuds, Sherlock able to taste George’s poor diet but he can lecture the man later. Right now he just wants to kiss him, hold him, be with him.

 

“I swallowed.” Sherlock smiles, his voice hoarse. “Does that prove to you I love you?”

 

“It proves you love cock.” George dismisses, turning his head when Sherlock tries to kiss him. “That’s gross.” George feels guilty at the disappointed look in Sherlock’s eyes. “Do you want me to... erm, reciprocate?” Sherlock laughs at George’s turn of phrase.

 

“You don’t have to.” Sherlock says. At first George doesn’t understand but a quick glance at Sherlock’s trousers solves that: a damp patch on the front, still soaking through.

 

“Wow, you must really love cock.” George comments. Sherlock grins.

 

“I’m gonna brush my teeth, and get cleaned up.” Sherlock tells him, wandering into the bathroom. By the time he comes out, with freshly brushed teeth, no top and blue cotton pyjama bottoms, Lestrade is getting dressed. “Don’t go.” Sherlock asks.

 

“You want me to stay the night?” Lestrade questions, his coat between his hands. Sherlock takes it and tosses it on the floor.

 

“I want you to stay forever.” Sherlock kisses him. “But a night sounds far more feasible for now.” Sherlock strips Lestrade of his still-damp clothes, toying with Lestrade’s boxers but Lestrade bats Sherlock’s hand away, making sure they stay on. Sherlock pouts. “Come to bed. I’m tired and so are you.” Sherlock reasons. Lestrade lets himself be dragged to Sherlock’s bed, getting under the covers immediately, just to stop feeling Sherlock’s eyes on his body. “Are you okay?” That question again, a silly question designed to pretend to you care about someone. Sherlock means it.

 

“I still don’t get it. I still don’t understand what you see in me.” George admits.

 

“I don’t understand how you see yourself.” Sherlock counters.

 

“A middle-aged copper with grey hair and an expanding stomach.” George tells him. “A cop. That’s who I am.”

 

“You’re the man I love.” Sherlock tells him, and this time George is too tired to wince. “Despite being a cop.” Sherlock can feel George’s breathing even out. “George?” Sherlock calls.

 

“Yes Sherlock?” George mutters, half asleep.

 

“You will be here, when I wake up, won’t you?” Sherlock asks. “You won’t leave?”

 

“I’ll never leave you.” George answers. “But you’ll get bored, and leave me.” George says, answering truthfully in his semi-conscious state, or rather, what he perceives to be the truth. Sherlock lets him fall asleep before wrapping his body around him.

 

“You are beautiful.” Sherlock whispers. “You can’t stop me loving you.” Sherlock promises, before falling asleep, curled against the body of his lover.

 

FIN
